title: How to Say Yes in French

steps.title: Say “oui” for a simple “yes.”
steps.content: Say “oui” for a simple “yes.” You can use this word in almost any circumstance, no matter how formal or informal it is. Pronounce this word by saying “wee.” [1] X Research source If you want to make this response more polite, you can add the French equivalent of “mister,” “missus,” or “miss” to the end of the term. Monsieur , pronounced muh-see-euh, translates into “mister.” Oui, monsieur. Madame , pronounced mah-dehm , translates into “missus.” Oui, madame. Mademoiselle , pronounced mah-dehm-mwah-zel , translates into “miss.” Oui, mademoiselle.

steps.title: Politely offer “oui, merci.”
steps.content: Politely offer “oui, merci.” This phrase means “yes, thanks.” It’s a great way to accept an offer politely. You should pronounce it like, “WEE, mare-SEE.” [2] X Research source Merci means “thanks” or “thank you.”

steps.title: Reply with “oui, s'il vous plaît.”
steps.content: Reply with “oui, s'il vous plaît.” This is another polite phrase. It means “yes, if it is pleasing to you,” or “yes, please.” Pronounce it like, WEE, sill voo PLEH . [3] X Research source S'il means “if.” Vous means “you.” Plaît means “please.”

steps.title: Casually respond with “ouais.”
steps.content: Casually respond with “ouais.” This is the French equivalent of the English “yeah.” Pronounce it like oo-way . [4] X Research source You should only use this in informal situations, like when you’re talking to your friends.

steps.title: Use “ouaip” instead.
steps.content: Use “ouaip” instead. This is the French equivalent of the English “yep.” It should be pronounced like oo-wayp . [5] X Research source This word is slightly less informal than the one above, but it’s still only good for casual situations. You can also say “oeup” if you want to sound like a cool teenager.

steps.title: Say “bah oui” for another way to say “yeah.”
steps.content: Say “bah oui” for another way to say “yeah.” You can never have too many ways to informally agree, right? Another phrase, pronounced bah WEE , is another casual affirmative. [6] X Research source There’s no difference between this phrase and “ouais,” so you can use them interchangeably.

steps.title: Use “mouais” if you’re not sure.
steps.content: Use “mouais” if you’re not sure. This phrase best translates to “um, yeah,” or “kinda sorta.” Pronounced mwé , you can say it when you’re not super sure if you want to say yes or not. [7] X Research source You might use this phrase if someone invites you to a party but it doesn’t sound very fun.

steps.title: Say “ouah” if you’re passionate about your “yes.”
steps.content: Say “ouah” if you’re passionate about your “yes.” Using this word adds an exclamation point onto your agreement. Pronounce it like wa , or the first part of the word “wow.” [8] X Research source You can use this to show your enthusiasm if you’re really excited about something.

steps.title: State “évidemment.”
steps.content: State “évidemment.” This translates into “obviously.” Pronounce this French word as eh-vee-dah-mo(n) . The N is silent! [9] X Research source This is a slightly sassy way to confirm something, so use it sparingly.

steps.title: Say “certainement.”
steps.content: Say “certainement.” In English, this means “definitely” or “surely.” You should pronounce this French term as sir-ten-mo(n) . Again, the N is silent! [10] X Research source This also roughly translates to “of course.”

steps.title: Respond with “carrément.”
steps.content: Respond with “carrément.” This word translates into the English word “firmly.” This French word should be pronounced as “kah-ray-mo(n).” [11] X Research source It can also mean “absolutely.”

steps.title: Reply with “tout à fait.”
steps.content: Reply with “tout à fait.” This phrase means “quite,” “completely,” or “altogether.” Pronounce this French phrase as too tah feh . [12] X Research source Tout means "all" or "whole." The French à means "with," "to," "by," or "in" when translated into English. Fait means "fact," "event" or "occurrence."

steps.title: Answer with "en effet."
steps.content: Answer with "en effet." This translates loosely into “indeed” or “in fact.” Pronounce this French phrase as on -ay-feh . [13] X Research source En means "in." Effet means "effect."

steps.title: Exclaim “bien sûr!”
steps.content: Exclaim “bien sûr!” This phrase loosely translates into “of course!” This French phrase should be pronounced as byahng soor . [14] X Research source Bien means “good” or “well.” Sûr means “sure” or “certain.”

steps.title: Use “exactement” when you’re sure about something.
steps.content: Use “exactement” when you’re sure about something. This French word translates to “exactly.” It’s pronounced as exacta-mah . [15] X Research source You can also use it when talking about something precise.

steps.title: Say “absolument” when something is possible.
steps.content: Say “absolument” when something is possible. You can use this word when you mean “completely.” Pronounce it as ab-so-loo-mah . [16] X Research source Even though there’s a “T” on the end of the word, you don’t pronounce it.

steps.title: Offer a polite “très bien.”
steps.content: Offer a polite “très bien.” Use this phrase to say “very well.” Pronounce this French phrase as tray byahng. [17] X Research source Très means “very.” Bien means “well” or “good."

steps.title: State “C'est bien.”
steps.content: State “C'est bien.” This phrase means “that's fine” in English. This French phrase should be pronounced as say byahng . C'est means “it is.” Bien means “well” or “good.”

steps.title: Say “Ça va.”
steps.content: Say “Ça va.” Use this phrase to offer a simple “okay.” When pronouncing this French phrase, pronounce it as sah vah . [18] X Research source Ça means “it.” Va is derived from the French verb aller, meaning “to go,” “to do,” or “to be.”

steps.title: Reply with “d'accord.”
steps.content: Reply with “d'accord.” The English equivalent of this French term is “agreed.” This French phrase should be pronounced as dah-korr . [19] X Research source It could also mean “okay” or “all right.”

steps.title: Exclaim “volontiers!”
steps.content: Exclaim “volontiers!” This phrase means “willingly!” or “gladly!” You should pronounce this French phrase as vol-on-tee-yay. [20] X Research source It’s another exciting word.

steps.title: Excitedly answer with “avec plaisir!”
steps.content: Excitedly answer with “avec plaisir!” In English, this phrase means “with pleasure!” You should pronounce this French phrase as ah-vehk play-zear . [21] X Research source Avec means “with.” Plaisir means “pleasure.”

steps.title: Say “ça marche.”
steps.content: Say “ça marche.” This translates as “okay, that works.” Pronounce this phrase as sah marsh . [22] X Research source This is one of the most common phrases in the French language for the affirmative, so it’s good to know!

steps.title: Use “c’est ça.”
steps.content: Use “c’est ça.” Literally translated, this phrase means “that’s it” or “exactly.” You can pronounce this phrase as say sah . [23] X Research source This is another way to say “you’re right.”

steps.title: Use this “yes” to say yes while also contradicting a statement.
steps.content: Use this “yes” to say yes while also contradicting a statement. It seems confusing, but there may come a time when you want to answer in the affirmative but not agree with the whole statement. You can use the contradictory yes to still agree while adding on information. [24] X Research source Literally, it means “but yes” or “actually, yes.”

steps.title: Say “si” for a contradictory yes.
steps.content: Say “si” for a contradictory yes. You can pronounce this word like see . It’s a quick, small word, so it can get lost in conversation. [25] X Research source It’s pronounced the same way as “yes” in Spanish.

steps.title: For example:
steps.content: For example: If someone asks, “You seem tired. Did you not sleep enough last night?” You might answer, “Yes I did sleep enough last night, I’m just tired from the trip.” This is a case where you would use the contradictory yes. [26] X Research source In French, your answer would be, “ Si j’ai assez dormi. Je suis juste fatigué du voyage.”
